Award.AwardTitle: The Cultural and Biological Significance of Ethnic Substructure in New Mexican Hispanics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research examines sociocultural and biological variation in Hispanic people in New Mexico, a state known for its unique history of early Spanish colonization and continuing immigration from Latin America. The multidisciplinary team is collecting data on ethnicity, genetics, morphology, and health from a diverse cross-section of the New Mexican public and using these data to examine how people construct ethnicity, the sociocultural and biological correlates of ethnicity, and the social causes of economic
inequality and health disparity. The project redresses limitations of previous research on race and ethnicity, including: 1) reliance on static US Census categories that do not fully capture how people think about ethnicity, 2) the assumption that people from a particular ethnic group are culturally and biologically homogeneous, 3) reliance on indirect or inadequate measures of sociocultural and biological variation, 4) the assumption that ethnic groups are stable in space and time, 5) the uncritical use of ethnicity as a proxy for genetic ancestry, and 6) the failure to employ a biocultural and evolutionary perspective.

The project provides training for several Hispanic undergraduate and graduate students. The public health policy implications of findings will be explored with faculty from the UNM Alfonso Ortiz Center for Intercultural Studies and the Institute for Race and Social Justice. Results will be communicated to the public via a web-based exhibit and by a panel exhibit that will travel throughout the state. The research will generate a comparative database from other US Hispanic groups that can be used by social scientists and medical health professionals. The results will be presented by the investigators and their students in leading scientific journals and at professional meetings.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research examines variation in genetic ancestry, socioeconomic status, and indicators of health variation in self-identified Hispanic people from New Mexico, a state known for its unique history of early Spanish colonization and continuing immigration from Latin America. Research questions include: Do Hispanic New Mexicans recognize ethnic subgroups? If so, what sociocultural and biological features distinguish subgroups? What role does ethnic identity play in health, and is this role genetic, sociocultural, or some combination of the two? How has continued immigration from Latin America affected ethnic identity and the health and welfare of New Mexicans? Do intermarriage and changing social norms affect the way people think about ethnicity?

The project is improving our understanding of how people construct ethnicity, the sociocultural and biological correlates of ethnic substructure, and the social causes of economic inequality and health disparity. For example, we have found that genetic ancestry, skin color, and ethnic sub-group membership do not predict health outcomes, such as high blood pressure and diabetes, in our sample. However, perception of social rank, as gauged by the MacArthur Foundation’s ladder scale, does predict health outcomes.

Intellectual merit: The project redresses limitations of previous research on race and ethnicity, including: 1) reliance on static US Census categories that do not fully capture how people think about ethnicity; 2) the assumption that people from a particular ethnic group are culturally and biologically homogeneous; 3) reliance on indirect or inadequate measures of cultural and biological variation; and 4) the assumption that ethnic groups are unchanging.

Broader impacts: The project is training several undergraduate and graduate students, including minority students. Results are currently being communicated to the public via an interactive website. After writing up initial publications, we will generate a comparative database from other US Hispanic groups that can be used by social scientists and medical health professionals. The results are being presented by the investigators and their students in leading scientific journals and at professional meetings. 

 


Last Modified: 06/05/2015
Modified by: Keith L Hunley
